an11.16:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṃ viharati beluvagāmake.
an11.16:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.

an11.16:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputtaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
an11.16:1.2.eng: Now at that time the householder Dasama, a wealthy citizen, had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business.

an11.16:2.1.pli: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro yena kukkuṭārāmo yena aññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
an11.16:2.1.eng: He went to the Chicken Monastery, approached a certain mendicant, and said to him,

an11.16:2.2.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho, bhante, āyasmā ānando etarahi viharati?
an11.16:2.2.eng: “Sir, where is Venerable Ānanda now staying?

an11.16:2.3.pli: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ, bhante, āyasmantaṃ ānandan”ti.
an11.16:2.3.eng: For I want to see him.”

an11.16:2.4.pli: “Eso, gahapati, āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṃ viharati beluvagāmake”ti.
an11.16:2.4.eng: “Householder, Venerable Ānanda is staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.”

an11.16:3.1.pli: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputte taṃ karaṇīyaṃ tīretvā yena vesālī beluvagāmako yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an11.16:3.1.eng: Then the householder Dasama, having concluded his business there, went to the little village of Beluva in Vesālī to see Ānanda. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:

an11.16:3.2.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇātī”ti?
an11.16:3.2.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, is there one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke?”

an11.16:3.3.pli: “Atthi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇātī”ti.

an11.16:4.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇātī”ti?

an11.16:4.2.pli: “Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an11.16:4.2.eng: “Householder, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an11.16:4.4.eng: ‘Even this first absorption is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:4.5.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ, tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:4.5.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:4.6.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:4.6.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:4.7.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:4.7.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:4.8.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an11.16:4.8.eng: This is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

an11.16:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe…
an11.16:5.1.eng: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …

an11.16:5.5.eng: ‘Even this fourth absorption is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:5.6.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:5.6.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:5.7.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:5.7.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:5.8.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:5.8.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:5.9.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an11.16:5.9.eng: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

an11.16:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
an11.16:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an11.16:6.3.eng: ‘Even this heart’s release by love is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:6.4.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:6.4.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:6.5.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:6.5.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:6.6.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:6.6.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:6.7.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an11.16:6.7.eng: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One …

an11.16:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
an11.16:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …

an11.16:7.2.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

an11.16:7.3.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ.
an11.16:7.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.

an11.16:7.4.pli: Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
an11.16:7.4.eng: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an11.16:7.6.eng: ‘Even this heart’s release by equanimity is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:7.7.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:7.7.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:7.8.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:7.8.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:7.9.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:7.9.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:7.10.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an11.16:7.10.eng: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One …

an11.16:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an11.16:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an11.16:8.3.eng: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of infinite space is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:8.4.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:8.4.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:8.5.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:8.5.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:8.6.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:8.6.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:8.7.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an11.16:8.7.eng: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One …

an11.16:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe…
an11.16:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …

an11.16:9.2.pli: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an11.16:9.2.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. …

an11.16:9.4.eng: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of nothingness is produced by choices and intentions.’

an11.16:9.5.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
an11.16:9.5.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

an11.16:9.6.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti;
an11.16:9.6.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an11.16:9.7.pli: no ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an11.16:9.7.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an11.16:9.8.pli: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
an11.16:9.8.eng: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they reach the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”

an11.16:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an11.16:10.1.eng: When he said this, the householder Dasama said to Venerable Ānanda:

an11.16:10.2.pli: “seyyathāpi, bhante ānanda, puriso ekaṃ nidhimukhaṃ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa nidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya;
an11.16:10.2.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, suppose a person was looking for the entrance to a treasure trove. And all at once they’d come across eleven entrances!

an11.16:10.3.pli: evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, ekaṃ amatadvāraṃ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa amatadvārāni alatthaṃ sevanāya.
an11.16:10.3.eng: In the same way, I was searching for the door to freedom from death. And all at once I found eleven doors to freedom from death for cultivation.

an11.16:10.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, purisassa agāraṃ ekādasa dvāraṃ. So tasmiṃ agāre āditte ekamekenapi dvārena sakkuṇeyya attānaṃ sotthiṃ kātuṃ;
an11.16:10.4.eng: Suppose a person had a house with eleven doors. If the house caught fire they’d be able to flee to safety through any one of those doors.

an11.16:10.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, imesaṃ ekādasannaṃ amatadvārānaṃ ekamekenapi amatadvārena sakkuṇissāmi attānaṃ sotthiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.16:10.5.eng: In the same way, I’m able to flee to safety through any one of these eleven doors to freedom from death.

an11.16:10.6.pli: Ime hi nāma, bhante, aññatitthiyā ācariyassa ācariyadhanaṃ pariyesissanti.
an11.16:10.6.eng: Sir, those of other religions will seek a fee for the tutor.

an11.16:10.7.pli: Kiṃ panāhaṃ āyasmato ānandassa pūjaṃ na karissāmī”ti.
an11.16:10.7.eng: Why shouldn’t I make an offering to Venerable Ānanda?”

an11.16:11.1.pli: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro vesālikañca pāṭaliputtakañca bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
an11.16:11.1.eng: Then the householder Dasama, having assembled the Saṅgha from Vesālī and Pāṭaliputta, served and satisfied them with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an11.16:11.2.pli: Ekamekañca bhikkhuṃ paccekaṃ dussayugena acchādesi, āyasmantañca ānandaṃ ticīvarena.
an11.16:11.2.eng: He clothed each and every mendicant in a pair of garments, with a set of three robes for Ānanda.

an11.16:11.3.eng: And he had a dwelling worth five hundred built for Ānanda.

an11.166-213:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Eye Contact, Etc.

an11.17:1.1.pli: “Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.17:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti, na vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṃ kattā hoti, na titthaṃ jānāti, na pītaṃ jānāti, na vīthiṃ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti, ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
an11.17:1.3.eng: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and captains of the herd.

an11.17:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.17:1.4.eng: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.17:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an11.17:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an11.17:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti, na vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṃ kattā hoti, na titthaṃ jānāti, na pītaṃ jānāti, na vīthiṃ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti, ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
an11.17:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

an11.17:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti?
an11.17:3.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not know form?

an11.17:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ (…) ‘cattāri mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an11.17:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.

an11.17:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti.
an11.17:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know form.

an11.17:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti?
an11.17:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant not skilled in characteristics?

an11.17:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘kammalakkhaṇo bālo, kammalakkhaṇo paṇḍito’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an11.17:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t understand that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.

an11.17:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti.
an11.17:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant isn’t skilled in characteristics.

an11.17:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti?
an11.17:5.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not pick out flies’ eggs?

an11.17:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti, uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ … uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ …
an11.17:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant tolerates a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.

an11.17:5.3.pli: uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an11.17:5.3.eng: They tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen. They don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an11.17:5.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti.
an11.17:5.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs.

an11.17:6.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti?
an11.17:6.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not dress wounds?

an11.17:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī;
an11.17:6.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they get caught up in the features and details.

an11.17:6.3.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjati; na rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ nāpajjati.
an11.17:6.3.eng: Since the faculty of sight is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of sight, and they don’t achieve its restraint.

an11.17:6.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an11.17:6.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an11.17:6.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an11.17:6.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an11.17:6.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī;
an11.17:6.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they get caught up in the features and details.

an11.17:6.9.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjati; na rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ nāpajjati.
an11.17:6.9.eng: Since the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of the mind, and they don’t achieve its restraint.

an11.17:6.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti.
an11.17:6.10.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t dress wounds.

an11.17:7.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṃ kattā hoti?
an11.17:7.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not spread smoke?

an11.17:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ desetā hoti.
an11.17:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.

an11.17:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṃ kattā hoti.
an11.17:7.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t spread smoke.

an11.17:8.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na titthaṃ jānāti?
an11.17:8.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not know the ford?

an11.17:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchati na paripañhati:
an11.17:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t from time to time go up to those mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and ask them questions:

an11.17:8.3.eng: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’

an11.17:8.4.pli: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva na vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca na uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ na paṭivinodenti.
an11.17:8.4.eng: Those venerables don’t reveal what is hidden, clarify what is unclear, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

an11.17:8.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na titthaṃ jānāti.
an11.17:8.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the ford.

an11.17:9.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pītaṃ jānāti?
an11.17:9.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not know satisfaction?

an11.17:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye desiyamāne na labhati atthavedaṃ, na labhati dhammavedaṃ, na labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.17:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds no inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds no joy connected with the teaching.

an11.17:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pītaṃ jānāti.
an11.17:9.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know satisfaction.

an11.17:10.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vīthiṃ jānāti?
an11.17:10.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not know the trail?

an11.17:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an11.17:10.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the noble eightfold path.

an11.17:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vīthiṃ jānāti.
an11.17:10.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the trail.

an11.17:11.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gocarakusalo hoti?
an11.17:11.1.eng: And how is a mendicant not skilled in pastures?

an11.17:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an11.17:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an11.17:11.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gocarakusalo hoti.
an11.17:11.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in pastures.

an11.17:12.1.eng: And how does a mendicant milk dry?

an11.17:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ saddhā gahapatikā abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavārenti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi. Tatra bhikkhu mattaṃ na jānāti paṭiggahaṇāya.
an11.17:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. But they don’t know moderation in accepting.

an11.17:12.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anavasesadohī hoti.
an11.17:12.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant milks dry.

an11.17:13.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti?
an11.17:13.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?

an11.17:13.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, tesu na mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca, na mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ … na mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca.
an11.17:13.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t consistently treat senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.

an11.17:13.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, na te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
an11.17:13.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

an11.17:14.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an11.17:14.1.eng: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an11.17:15.1.pli: Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako bhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.17:15.1.eng: A cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.17:15.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako rūpaññū hoti, lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti, vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti, dhūmaṃ kattā hoti, titthaṃ jānāti, pītaṃ jānāti, vīthiṃ jānāti, gocarakusalo hoti, sāvasesadohī ca hoti, ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti—
an11.17:15.3.eng: It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and captains of the herd.

an11.17:15.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako bhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
an11.17:15.4.eng: A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.17:16.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an11.17:16.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

an11.17:16.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaññū hoti, lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti, vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti, dhūmaṃ kattā hoti, titthaṃ jānāti, pītaṃ jānāti, vīthiṃ jānāti, gocarakusalo hoti, sāvasesadohī ca hoti, ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
an11.17:16.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

an11.17:17.1.eng: And how does a mendicant know form?

an11.17:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ ‘cattāri mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an11.17:17.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands that all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.

an11.17:17.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaññū hoti.
an11.17:17.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows form.

an11.17:18.1.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in characteristics?

an11.17:18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘kammalakkhaṇo bālo, kammalakkhaṇo paṇḍito’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an11.17:18.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.

an11.17:18.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu lakkhaṇakusalo hoti.
an11.17:18.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in characteristics.

an11.17:19.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti?
an11.17:19.1.eng: And how does a mendicant pick out flies’ eggs?

an11.17:19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti, uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ … uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ … uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an11.17:19.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and exterminates it. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an11.17:19.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsāṭikaṃ hāretā hoti.
an11.17:19.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant picks out flies’ eggs.

an11.17:20.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti?
an11.17:20.1.eng: And how does a mendicant dress wounds?

an11.17:20.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
an11.17:20.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an11.17:20.3.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an11.17:20.3.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

an11.17:20.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an11.17:20.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an11.17:20.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an11.17:20.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an11.17:20.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
an11.17:20.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an11.17:20.9.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an11.17:20.9.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

an11.17:20.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇaṃ paṭicchādetā hoti.
an11.17:20.10.eng: That’s how a mendicant dresses wounds.

an11.17:21.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhūmaṃ kattā hoti?
an11.17:21.1.eng: And how does a mendicant spread smoke?

an11.17:21.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ desetā hoti.
an11.17:21.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant teaches others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.

an11.17:21.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhūmaṃ kattā hoti.
an11.17:21.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant spreads smoke.

an11.17:22.1.eng: And how does a mendicant know the ford?

an11.17:22.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati:
an11.17:22.2.eng: It’s when from time to time a mendicant goes up to those mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and asks them questions:

an11.17:22.3.eng: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’

an11.17:22.4.pli: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ paṭivinodenti.
an11.17:22.4.eng: Those venerables reveal what is hidden, clarify what is unclear, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

an11.17:22.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu titthaṃ jānāti.
an11.17:22.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows the ford.

an11.17:23.1.eng: And how does a mendicant know satisfaction?

an11.17:23.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye desiyamāne labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.17:23.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an11.17:23.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītaṃ jānāti.
an11.17:23.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows satisfaction.

an11.17:24.1.eng: And how does a mendicant know the trail?

an11.17:24.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an11.17:24.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the noble eightfold path.

an11.17:24.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vīthiṃ jānāti.
an11.17:24.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows the trail.

an11.17:25.1.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in pastures?

an11.17:25.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an11.17:25.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an11.17:25.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gocarakusalo hoti.
an11.17:25.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in pastures.

an11.17:26.1.eng: And how does a mendicant not milk dry?

an11.17:26.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhā gahapatikā abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavārenti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
an11.17:26.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an11.17:26.3.eng: And that mendicant knows moderation in accepting.

an11.17:26.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sāvasesadohī hoti.
an11.17:26.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t milk dry.

an11.17:27.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti?
an11.17:27.1.eng: And how does a mendicant show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?

an11.17:27.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, tesu mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca, mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ … mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca.
an11.17:27.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant consistently treats senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.

an11.17:27.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
an11.17:27.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.

an11.17:28.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjitun”ti.
an11.17:28.1.eng: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.”
